langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following.

body.stage: Actus Primus. Scoena Prima. Flourish of Trumpets: Then Hoboyes">. Enter King, Duke Humfrey, Salisbury, Warwicke, and Beauford on the one side. The Queene, Suffolke, Yorke, Somerset, and Buckingham, on the other.

sp.speaker: Suffolke.
sp.l: As by your high Imperial Majesty,
I had in charge at my depart for France,
As Procurator to your Excellence,
To marry Princes Margaret for your Grace;
So in the Famous Ancient City, Toures,
In presence of the Kings of France, and Sicill,
The Dukes of Orleance, Calaber, Britain, and Alanson,
Seven Earls, twelve Barons, and twenty reverend Bishops
I have performed my Task, and was espoused,
And humbly now upon my bended knee,
In sight of England, and her Lordly Peers,
Deliver up my Title in the Queen
To your most gracious hands, that are the Substance
Of that great Shadow I did represent:
The happiest Gift, that ever Marquess gave,
The Fairest Queen, that ever King received.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Suffolke arise. Welcome Queen Margaret,
I can express no kinder sign of Love
Than this kind kiss: O Lord, that lends me life,
Lend me a heart replete with thankfulness:
For thou hast given me in this beauteous Face
A world of earthly blessings to my soul,
If Sympathy of Love unite our thoughts.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Great King of England, and my gracious Lord,
The mutual conference that my mind hath had,
By day, by night; waking, and in my dreams,
In Courtly company, or at my Beads,
With you mine Alder liefest Sovereign,
Makes me the bolder to salute my King,
With ruder terms, such as my wit affords,
And over joy of heart doth minister.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Her sight did ravish, but her grace in Speech,
Her words yclad with wisdoms Majesty,
Makes me from Wondering, fall to Weeping joys,
Such is the Fulness of my hearts content.
Lords, with one cheerful voice, Welcome my Love.
Long live Queen. Margaret, Englands happiness.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: We thank you all.

sp.speaker: Suf.
sp.l: My Lord Protector, so it please your Grace,
Here are the Articles of contracted peace,
Between our Sovereign, and the French King Charles,
For eighteen months concluded by consent.

p.hi:
Inprimis, It is agreed between the French King
Charles, and William de la Pole Marquess of Suffolke, Ambassador
for Henry King of England, That the said Henry shall
espouse the Lady Margaret, daughter unto Reignier King of
Naples, Sicillia, and Jerusalem, and Crown her Queen of
England, ere the thirtieth of May next ensuing.
Item, That the Duchy of Aniou, and the County of Main,
shall be released and delivered to the King her father.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Uncle, how now?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Pardon me gracious Lord,
Some sudden qualm hath struck me at the heart,
And dimmed mine eyes, that I can read no further.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Uncle of Winchester, I pray read on.

p.hi:
Item, It is further agreed between them, That the
Duchess of Aniou and Maine, shall be released and delivered
over to the King her Father, and she sent over of the King of
Englands own proper Cost and Charges, without having any Dowry.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: They please us well. Lord Marquis kneel down,
We here create thee the first Duke of Suffolke,
And girt thee with the Sword. Cousin of Yorke,
We here discharge your Grace from being Regent
In the parts of France, till term of eighteen Months
Be full expired. Thanks Uncle Winchester,
Gloster, Yorke, Buckingham, Somerset,
Salisburie, and Warwicke.
We thank you all for this great favour done,
In entertainment to my Princely Queen.
Come, let us in, and with all speed provide
To see her Coronation be performed.

body.stage: Exit King, Queene, and Suffolke. Manet the rest.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Brave Peers of England, Pillars of the State,
To you Duke Humfrey must unload his grief:
Your grief, the common grief of all the Land.
What? did my brother Henry spend his youth,
His valour, coin, and people in the wars?
Did he so often lodge in open field:
In Winters cold, and Summers parching heat,
To conquer France, his true inheritance?
And did my brother Bedford toil his wits,
To keep by policy what Henrie got:
Have you yourselves, Somerset, Buckingham,
Brave Yorke, Salisbury, and victorious Warwicke,
Received deep scars in France and Normandie:
Or hath mine Uncle Beauford, and myself,
With all the Learned Counsel of the Realm,
Studied so long, sat in the Council house,
Early and late, debating to and fro
How France and Frenchmen might be kept in awe,
And hath his Highness in his infancy,
Crowned in Paris in despite of foes,
And shall these Labours, and these Honours die?
Shall Henries Conquest, Bedfords vigilance,
Your Deeds of War, and all our Counsel die?
O Peers of England, shameful is this League,
Fatal this Marriage, cancelling your Fame,
Blotting your names from Books of memory,
Racing the Characters of your Renown,
Defacing Monuments of Conquered France,
Undoing all as all had never been.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Nephew, what means this passionate discourse?
This preroration with such circumstance:
For France, it is ours; and we will keep it still.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Aye Uncle, we will keep it, if we can:
But now it is impossible we should.
Suffolke, the new made Duke that rules the roost,
Hath given the Duchy of Aniou and Mayne,
Unto the poor King Reignier, whose large style
Agrees not with the leanness of his purse.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: Now by the death of him that died for all,
These Counties were the Keys of Normandie:
But wherefore weeps Warwicke, my valiant son?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: For grief that they are past recovery.
For were there hope to conquer them again,
My sword should shed hot blood, mine eyes no tears.
Aniou and Maine? Myself did win them both:
Those Provinces, these Arms of mine did conquer,
And are the Cities that I got with wounds,
Delivered up again with peaceful words?

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: For Suffolkes Duke, may he be suffocate,
That dims the Honour of this Warlike Isle:
France should have torn and rent my very heart,
Before I would have yielded to this League.
I never read but Englands Kings have had
Large sums of Gold, and Dowries with their wives,
And our King Henry gives away his own,
To match with her that brings no vantages.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: A proper jest, and never heard before,
That Suffolke should demand a whole Fifteenth,
For Costs and Charges in transporting her:
She should have staid in France, and starved in France
Before

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: My Lord of Gloster, now ye grow too hot,
It was the pleasure of my Lord the King.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: My Lord of Winchester I know your mind.
It is not my speeches that you do mislike:
But it is my presence that doth trouble ye,
Rancour will out, proud Prelate, in thy face
I see thy fury: If I longer stay,
We shall begin our ancient bickerings:
Lordings farewell, and say when I am gone,
I prophesied, France will be lost ere long.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: So, there goes our Protector in a rage:
It is known to you he is mine enemy:
Nay more, an enemy unto you all,
And no great friend, I fear me to the King;
Consider Lords, he is the next of blood,
And heir apparent to the English Crown:
Had Henrie got an Empire by his marriage,
And all the wealthy Kingdoms of the West,
There is reason he should be displeased at it:
Look to it Lords, let not his smoothing words
Bewitch your hearts, be wise and circumspect.
What though the common people favour him,
Calling him, Humfrey the good Duke of Gloster,
Clapping their hands, and crying with loud voice,
Iesu maintain your Royal Excellence,
With God preserve the good Duke Humfrey:
I fear me Lords, for all this flattering gloss,
He will be found a dangerous Protector.

sp.speaker: Buc.
sp.l: Why should he then protect our Sovereign?
He being of age to govern of himself.
Cousin of Somerset, join you with me,
And altogether with the Duke of Suffolke,
We will quickly hoise Duke Humfrey from his seat.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: This weighty business will not brooke delay,
I will to the Duke of Suffolke presently.

sp.speaker: Som.
sp.l: Cousin of Buckingham, though Humfries pride
And greatness of his place be grief to us,
Yet let us watch the haughty Cardinal,
His insolence is more intolerable
Than all the Princes in the Land beside,
If Gloster be displaced, he will be Protector.

sp.speaker: Buc.
sp.l: Or thou, or I Somerset will be Protectors,
Despite Duke Humfrey, or the Cardinal.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.l: Pride went before, Ambition follows him.
While these do labour for their own preferment,
Behooves it us to labour for the Realm.
I never saw but Humfrey Duke of Gloster,
Did bear him like a Noble Gentleman:
Oft have I seen the haughty Cardinal.
More like a Soldier than a man of the Church,
As stout and proud as he were Lord of all,
Swear like a Ruffian, and demean himself
Unlike the Ruler of a Common-weal.
Warwicke my son, the comfort of my age;
Thy deeds, thy plainness, and thy housekeeping,
Hath won the greatest favour of the Commons,
Excepting none but good Duke Humfrey.
And Brother Yorke, thy Acts in Ireland,
In bringing them to civil Discipline:
Thy late exploits done in the heart of France,
When thou wert Regent for our Sovereign,
Have made thee feared and honoured of the people,
Join we together for the public good,
In what we can, to bridle and suppress
The pride of Suffolke, and the Cardinal,
With Somersets and Buckinghams Ambition,
And as we may, cherish Duke Humfries deeds,
While they do tend the profit of the Land.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: So God help Warwicke, as he loves the Land,
And common profit of his Country.

sp.speaker: Yor.
sp.l: And so says Yorke,
For he hath greatest cause.

sp.speaker: Salisbury.
sp.l: Then let us make haste away,
And look unto the maine.

sp.speaker: Warwicke.
sp.l: Unto the maine?
O Father, Maine is lost,
That Maine, which by main force Warwicke did win,
And would have kept, so long as breath did last:
Main-chance father you meant, but I meant Maine,
Which I will win from France, or else be slain.

body.stage: Exit Warwicke, and Salisbury. Manet Yorke.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: Aniou and Maine are given to the French,
Paris is lost, the state of Normandie.
Stands on a tickle point, now they are gone:
Suffolke concluded on the Articles,
The Peers agreed, and Henry was well pleased,
To change two Dukedoms for a Dukes fair daughter.
I cannot blame them all, what is it to them?
It is thine they give away, and not their own.
Pirates may make cheap pennyworths of their pillage,
And purchase Friends, and give to Courtesans,
Still revelling like Lords till all be gone,
While as the silly Owner of the goods
Weeps over them, and wrings his hapless hands,
And shakes his head, and trembling stands aloof,
While all is shared, and all is borne away,
Ready to starve, and dare not touch his own.
So Yorke must fit, and fret, and bite his tongue,
While his own Lands are bargained for, and sold:
Methinks the Realms of England, France, and Ireland,
Bear that proportion to my flesh and blood,
As did the fatal brand Althoea burnt,
Unto the Princes heart of Calidon:
Aniou and Maine both given unto the French?
Cold news for me: for I had hope of France,
Even as I have of fertile Englands soil.
A day will come, when Yorke shall claim his own,
And therefore I will take the Neuils parts,
And make a show of love to proud Duke Humfrey,
And when I spy advantage, claim the Crown,
For that is the Golden mark I seek to hit:
Nor shall proud Lancaster usurp my right,
Nor hold the Sceptre in his childish Fist,
Nor wear the Diadem upon his head,
Whose Church-like humours fits not for a Crown.
Then Yorke be still awhile, till time do serve:
Watch thou, and wake when others be asleep,
To pry into the secrets of the State,
Till Henrie surfeiting in joys of love,
With his new Bride, and Englands dear bought Queen,
And Humfrey with the Peers be fallen at jars:
Then will I raise aloft the milk-white rose,
With whose sweet smell the Air shall be perfumed,
And in my Standard bear the Arms of Yorke,
To grapple with the house of Lancaster,
And force perforce I will make him yield the Crown,
Whose bookish Rule, hath pulled fair England down.

body.stage: Exit Yorke. Enter Duke Humfrey and his wife Elianor.

sp.speaker: Elia.
sp.l: Why droops my Lord like overripened Corn,
Hanging the head at Ceres plenteous load?
Why doth the Great Duke Humfrey knit his brows,
As frowning at the Favours of the world?
Why are thine eyes fixed to the sullen earth,
Gazing on that which seems to dim thy sight?
What seest thou there? King Henries Diadem,
Enchased with all the Honours of the world?
If so, Gaze on, and grovel on thy face,
Until thy head be circled with the same.
Put forth thy hand, reach at the glorious Gold.
What, is it too short? I will lengthen it with mine,
And having both together heaved it up,
We will both together lift our heads to heaven,
And never more abase our sight so low,
As to vouchsafe one glance unto the ground.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: O Nell, sweet Nell, if thou dost love thy Lord,
Banish the Canker of ambitious thoughts:
And may that thought, when I imagine ill
Against my King and Nephew, virtuous Henry,
Be my last breathing in this mortal world.
My troublous dreams this night, doth make me sad.

sp.speaker: Eli.
sp.l: What dreamed my Lord, tell me, and I will requite it
With sweet rehearsal of my mornings dream?

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: Methought this staff mine Office-badge in Court
Was broke in twain: by whom, I have forgot,
But as I think, it was by the Cardinal,
And on the pieces of the broken Wand
Were placed, the heads of Edmond Duke of Somerset,
And William de la Pole first Duke of Suffolke.
This was my dream, what it doth bode God knows.

sp.speaker: Eli.
sp.l: Tut, this was nothing but an argument,
That he that breaks a stick of Glosters grove,
Shall loose his head for his presumption.
But list to me my Humfrey, my sweet Duke:
Methought I sat in Seat of Majesty,
In the Cathedral Church of Westminster,
And in that Chair where Kings and Queens were crowned,
Where Henrie and Dame Margaret kneeled to me,
And on my head did set the Diadem.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: Nay Elinor, then must I chide outright:
Presumptuous Dame, ill nurtured Elianor,
Art thou not second Woman in the Realm?
And the Protectors wife beloved of him?
Hast thou not worldly pleasure at command,
Above the reach or compass of thy thought?
And wilt thou still be hammering Treachery,
To tumble down thy husband, and thyself,
From top of Honour, to Disgraces feet?
Away from me, and let me hear no more.

sp.speaker: Elia.
sp.l: What, what, my Lord? Are you so choleric
With Elianor, for telling but her dream?
Next time I will keep my dreams unto myself,
And not be checked.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: Nay be not angry, I am pleased again.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: My Lord Protector, it is his Highness pleasure,
You do prepare to ride unto Saint Albons,
Where as the King and Queen do mean to Hawk.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: I go. Come Nel thou wilt ride with us?

sp.speaker: Eli.
sp.l: Yes my good Lord, I will follow presently.
Follow I must, I cannot go before,
While Gloster bears this base and humble mind.
Were I a Man, a Duke, and next of blood,
I would remove these tedious stumbling blocks,
And smooth my way upon their headless necks.
And being a woman, I will not be slack
To play my part in Fortunes Pageant.
Where are you there? Sir Iohn; nay fear not man,
We are alone, here is none but thee, and I.

sp.speaker: Hume.
sp.l: Iesus preserve your Royal Majesty.

sp.speaker: Elia.
sp.l: What sayst thou? Majesty: I am but Grace.

sp.speaker: Hume.
sp.l: But by the grace of God, and Humes advice,
Your Graces Title shall be multiplied.

sp.speaker: Elia.
sp.l: What sayst thou man? Hast thou as yet conferred
With Margerie Iordane the cunning Witch,
With Roger Bollingbrooke the Conjurer?
And will they undertake to do me good?

sp.speaker: Hume.
sp.l: This they have promised to show your Highness
A Spirit raised from depth of under ground,
That shall make answer to such Questions,
As by your Grace shall be propounded him.

sp.speaker: Elianor.
sp.l: It is enough, I will think upon the Questions:
When from Saint Albones we do make return,
We will see these things effected to the full.
Here Hume, take this reward, make merry man
With thy Confederates in this weighty cause.

sp.speaker: Hume.
sp.l: Hume must make merry with the Duchess Gold:
Marry and shall: but how now, Sir Iohn Hume?
Seal up your Lips, and give no words but Mum,
The business asketh silent secrecy.
Dame Elianor gives Gold, to bring the Witch:
Gold cannot come amiss, were she a Devil.
Yet have I Gold flies from another Coast:
I dare not say, from the rich Cardinal,
And from the great and new-made Duke of Suffolke;
Yet I do find it so: for to be plain,
They (knowing Dame Elianors aspiring humour)
Have hired me to undermine the Duchess,
And buzz these Conjurations in her brain.
They say, A crafty Knave does need no Broker,
Yet am I Suffolke and the Cardinals Broker.
Hume, if you take not heed, you shall go near
To call them both a pair of crafty Knaves.
Well, so it stands: and thus I fear at last,
Humes Knavery will be the Duchess Wrack,
And her Attainture, will be Humphreyes fall:
Sort how it will, I shall have Gold for all.

body.stage: Exit Enter three or foure Petitioners, the Armorers Man being one.

sp.speaker: 1. Pet.
sp.p: My Masters, let us stand close, my Lord Protector will come this way by and by, and then we may deliver our Supplications in the Quill.

sp.speaker: 2. Pet.
sp.p: Marry the Lord protect him, for he is a good man, Iesu bless him.

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: Here he comes methinks, and the Queen with him: I will be the first sure.

sp.speaker: 2. Pet.
sp.p: Come back fool, this is the Duke of Suffolk, and not my Lord Protector.

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.l: How now fellow: wouldst anything with me?

sp.speaker: 1. Pet.
sp.p: I pray my Lord pardon me, I took ye for my Lord Protector.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.p: To my Lord Protector? Are your Supplications to his Lordship? Let me see them: what is thine?

sp.speaker: 1. Pet.
sp.p: Mine is, if it please your Grace, against Iohn Goodman, my Lord Cardinals Man, for keeping my House, and Lands, and Wife and all, from me.

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.p: Thy Wife too? that is some Wrong indeed. What is yours? What is here Against the Duke of Suffolke, for enclosing the Commons of Melforde. How now, Sir Knave?

sp.speaker: 2. Pet.
sp.p: Alas Sir, I am but a poor Petitioner of our whole Township.

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: Against my Master Thomas Horner, for saying, That the Duke of Yorke was rightful Heir to the Crown.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.p: What sayst thou? Did the Duke of Yorke say, he was rightful Heir to the Crown?

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: That my Mistress was? No forsooth: my Master said, That he was, and that the King was an Usurper.

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.p: Who is there?
Take this fellow in, and send for his Master with a Pursuivant presently: we will hear more of your matter before the King.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: And as for you that love to be protected
Under the Wings of our Protectors Grace,
Begin your Suites anew, and sue to him.
Away, base Cullions: Suffolke let them go.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Come, let us be gone.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: My Lord of Suffolke, say, is this the guise?
Is this the Fashions in the Court of England?
Is this the Government of Britains Isle?
And this the Royalty of Albions King?
What, shall King Henry be a Pupil still,
Under the surly Glosters Governance?
Am I a Queen in Title and in Style,
And must be made a Subject to a Duke?
I tell thee Poole, when in the City Tours
Thou rannest a tilt in honour of my Love,
And stolest away the Ladies hearts of France;
I thought King Henry had resembled thee,
In Courage, Courtship, and Proportion:
But all his mind is bent to Holiness,
To number Ave-Maries on his Beads:
His Champions, are the Prophets and Apostles,
His Weapons, holy Saws of sacred Writ,
His Study is his Tilt-yard, and his Loves
Are brazen Images of Canonised Saints.
I would the College of the Cardinals
Would choose him Pope; and carry him to Rome,
And set the Triple Crown upon his Head;
That were a State fit for his Holiness.

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.l: Madam be patient: as I was cause
Your Highness came to England, so will I
In England work your Graces full content.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: Beside the haughty Protector, have we Beauford
The imperious Churchman; Somerset, Buckingham,
And grumbling Yorke: and not the least of these,
But can do more in England than the King.

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.l: And he of these, that can do most of all,
Cannot do more in England than the Neuils:
Salisbury and Warwick are no simple Peers.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: Not all these Lords do vex me half so much,
As that proud Dame, the Lord Protectors Wife:
She sweeps it through the Court with troops of Ladies,
More like an Empress, than Duke Humphreyes Wife:
Strangers in Court, do take her for the Queen:
She bears a Dukes Revenues on her back,
And in her heart she scorns our Poverty:
Shall I not live to be avenged on her?
Contemptuous base-borne Callet as she is,
She vaunted amongst her Minions the other day,
The very train of her worst wearing Gown,
Was better worth than all my Fathers Lands,
Till Suffolke gave two Dukedoms for his Daughter.

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.l: Madam, myself have limed a Bush for her,
And placed a Choir of such enticing Birds,
That she will light to listen to the Lays,
And never mount to trouble you again.
So let her rest: and Madam list to me,
For I am bold to counsel you in this;
Although we fancy not the Cardinal,
Yet must we join with him and with the Lords,
Till we have brought Duke Humphrey in disgrace.
As for the Duke of Yorke, this late Complaint
Will make but little for his benefit:
So one by one we will weed them all at last,
And you yourself shall steer the happy Helm.

body.stage: Exit. Sound a Sennet. Enter the King, Duke Humfrey, Cardinall, Buckingham, Yorke, Salisbury, Warwicke, and the Duchesse.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: For my part, Noble Lords, I care not which,
Or Somerset, or Yorke, all is one to me.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: If Yorke have ill demeaned himself in France,
Then let him be denied the Regent-ship.

sp.speaker: Som.
sp.l: If Somerset be unworthy of the Place,
Let Yorke be Regent, I will yield to him.

sp.speaker: Warw.
sp.l: Whether your Grace be worthy, yea or no,
Dispute not that, Yorke is the worthier.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Ambitious Warwicke, let thy betters speak.

sp.speaker: Warw.
sp.l: The Cardinal is not my better in the field.

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.l: All in this presence are thy betters, Warwicke.

sp.speaker: Warw.
sp.l: Warwicke may live to be the best of all.

sp.speaker: Salisb.
sp.l: Peace Son, and show some reason Buckingham
Why Somerset should be preferred in this?

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: Because the King forsooth will have it so.

sp.speaker: Humf.
sp.l: Madam, the King is old enough himself
To give his Censure: These are no Women's matters.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: If he be old enough, what needs your Grace
To be Protector of his Excellence?

sp.speaker: Humf.
sp.l: Madam, I am Protector of the Realm,
And at his pleasure will resign my Place.

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.l: Resign it then, and leave thine insolence.
Since thou wert King; as who is King, but thou?
The Common-wealth hath daily run to wrack,
The Dolphin hath prevailed beyond the Seas,
And all the Peers and Nobles of the Realm
Have been as bondmen to thy Sovereignty.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: The Commons hast thou racked, the Clergies Bags
Are lank and lean with thy Extortions.

sp.speaker: Som.
sp.l: Thy sumptuous Buildings, and thy Wives Attire
Have cost a mass of public Treasury.

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.l: Thy Cruelty in execution
Upon Offenders, hath exceeded Law,
And left thee to the mercy of the Law.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: Thy sale of Offices and Towns in France,
If they were known, as the suspect is great,
Would make thee quickly hop without thy Head.
Give me my Fan: what, Minion, can ye not?
sp.stage: She giues the Duchesse a box on the eare.
sp.l: I cry you mercy, Madam: was it you?

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: Was it I? yea, I it was, proud French-woman:
Could I come near your Beauty with my Nails,
I could set my ten Commandments in your face.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Sweet Aunt be quiet, it was against her will.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: Against her will, good King? look to it in time,
She will hamper thee, and dandle thee like a Baby:
Though in this place most Master wear no Breeches,
She shall not strike Dame Elianor unrevenged.

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.l: Lord Cardinal, I will follow Elianor,
And listen after Humfrey, how he proceeds:
She is tickled now, her Fume needs no spurs,
She will gallop far enough to her destruction.

sp.speaker: Humf.
sp.l: Now Lords, my Choler being overblown,
With walking once about the Quadrangle,
I come to talk of Common-wealth Affairs.
As for your spiteful false Objections,
Prove them, and I lie open to the Law:
But God in mercy so deal with my Soul,
As I in duty love my King and Country.
But to the matter that we have in hand:
I say, my Sovereign, Yorke is meetest man
To be your Regent in the Realm of France.

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.l: Before we make election, give me leave
To show some reason, of no little force,
That Yorke is most unmeet of any man.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: I will tell thee, Suffolke, why I am unmeet.
First, for I cannot flatter thee in Pride:
Next, if I be appointed for the Place,
My Lord of Somerset will keep me here,
Without Discharge, Money, or Furniture,
Till France be won into the Dolphins hands:
Last time I danced attendance on his will,
Till Paris was besieged, famished, and lost.

sp.speaker: Warw.
sp.l: That can I witness, and a fouler fact
Did never Traitor in the Land commit.

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.l: Peace headstrong Warwicke.

sp.speaker: Warw.
sp.l: Image of Pride, why should I hold my peace?

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.l: Because here is a man accused of Treason,
Pray God the Duke of Yorke excuse himself.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: Doth anyone accuse Yorke for a Traitor?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What meanest thou, Suffolke? tell me, what are these?

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.l: Please it your Majesty, this is the man
That doth accuse his Master of High Treason;
His words were these: That Richard, Duke of Yorke,
Was rightful Heir unto the English Crown,
And that your Majesty was an Usurper.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Say man, were these thy words?

sp.speaker: Armorer.
sp.p: If it shall please your Majesty, I never said nor thought any such matter: God is my witness, I am falsely accused by the Villain.

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: By these ten bones, my Lords, he did speak them to me in the Garret one Night, as we were scouring my Lord of Yorkes Armour.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: Base Dunghill Villain, and Mechanical,
I will have thy Head for this thy Traitors speech:
I do beseech your Royal Majesty,
Let him have all the rigour of the Law.

sp.speaker: Armorer.
sp.p: Alas, my Lord, hang me if ever I spake the words: my accuser is my Prentice, and when I did correct him for his fault the other day, he did vow upon his knees he would be even with me: I have good witness of this; therefore I beseech your Majesty, do not cast away an honest man for a Villains accusation.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Uncle, what shall we say to this in law?

sp.speaker: Humf.
sp.l: This doom, my Lord, if I may judge:
Let Somerset be Regent over the French,
Because in Yorke this breeds suspicion;
And let these have a day appointed them
For single Combat, in convenient place,
For he hath witness of his servants malice:
This is the Law, and this Duke Humfreyes doom.

sp.speaker: Som.
sp.l: I humbly thank your Royal Majesty.

sp.speaker: Armorer.
sp.p: And I accept the Combat willingly.

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p:
Alas, my Lord, I cannot fight; for Gods sake pity my case: the spite of man prevaileth against me.
O Lord have mercy upon me, I shall never be able to fight a blow: O Lord my heart.

sp.speaker: Humf.
sp.p: Sirrah, or you must fight, or else be hanged.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Away with them to Prison: and the day of Combat, shall be the last of the next month. Come Somerset, we will see thee sent away.

body.stage: Flourish. Exeunt. Enter the Witch, the two Priests, and Bullingbrooke.

sp.speaker: Hume.
sp.p: Come my Masters, the Duchess I tell you expects performance of your promises.

sp.speaker: Bulling.
sp.p:
Master Hume, we are therefore provided: will
her Ladyship behold and hear our Exorcisms?

sp.speaker: Hume.
sp.p: Aye, what else? fear you not her courage.

sp.speaker: Bulling.
sp.p:
I have heard her reported to be a Woman of
an invincible spirit: but it shall be convenient, Master
Hume, that you be by her aloft, while we be busy below; and so I pray you go in Gods Name, and leave us
Mother Iordan, be you prostrate, and grovel on the Earth; Iohn Southwell read you, and let us to our work.

sp.speaker: Elianor.
sp.p: Well said my Masters, and welcome all: To this gear, the sooner the better.

sp.speaker: Bullin.
sp.l: Patience, good Lady, Wizards know their times:
Deep Night, dark Night, the silent of the Night,
The time of Night when Troy was set on fire,
The time when Screech-owls cry, and Bandogs howl,
And Spirits walk, and Ghosts break up their Graves;
That time best fits the work we have in hand.
Madam, sit you, and fear not: whom we raise,
We will make fast within a hallowed Verge.

body.stage: Here doethe Ceremonies belonging, and make the Circle, Bullingbrooke or Southwell reades, Coniuro te, &c. It Thunders and Lightens terribly: then the Spirit riseth.

sp.speaker: Witch.
sp.l: Asmath, by the eternal God,
Whose name and power thou tremblest at,
Answer that I shall ask: for till thou speak,
Thou shalt not pass from hence.

sp.speaker: Spirit.
sp.p: Ask what thou wilt; that I had said, and done.

sp.speaker: Bulling.
sp.l: First of the King: What shall of him become?

sp.speaker: Spirit.
sp.l: The Duke yet lives, that Henry shall depose:
But him outlive, and die a violent death.

sp.speaker: Bulling.
sp.l: What fates await the Duke of Suffolke?

sp.speaker: Spirit.
sp.l: By Water shall he die, and take his end.

sp.speaker: Bulling.
sp.l: What shall befall the Duke of Somerset?

sp.speaker: Spirit.
sp.l: Let him shun Castles,
Safer shall he be upon the sandy Plains,
Than where Castles mounted stand.
Have done, for more I hardly can endure.

sp.speaker: Bulling.
sp.l: Descend to Darkness, and the burning Lake:
False Fiend avoid.

body.stage: Thunder and Lightning. Exit Spirit. Enter the Duke of Yorke and the Duke of Buckingham with their Guard, and breake in.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: Lay hands upon these Traitors, and their trash:
Beldam I think we watched you at an inch.
What Madam, are you there? the King and Common-weal
Are deeply indebted for this piece of pains;
My Lord Protector will, I doubt it not,
See you well guerdoned for these good deserts.

sp.speaker: Elianor.
sp.l: Not half so bad as thine to Englands King,
Injurious Duke, that threatest where is no cause.

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.l: True Madam, none at all: what call you this?
Away with them, let them be clapped up close,
And kept asunder: you Madam shall with us.
Stafford take her to thee.
We will see your Trinkets here all forthcoming.
All away.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: Lord Buckingham, methinks you watched her well:
A pretty Plot, well chosen to build upon,
Now pray my Lord, let us see the Devils Writ.
What have we here?
The Duke yet lives, that Henry shall depose:
But him outlive, and die a violent death.
Why this is just, Aio AEacida Romanos vincere posso.
Well, to the rest:
Tell me what fate awaits the Duke of Suffolke?
By Water shall he die, and take his end.
What shall betide the Duke of Somerset?
Let him shun Castles,
Safer shall he be upon the sandy Plains,
Than where Castles mounted stand.
Come, come, my Lords,
These Oracles are hardly attained,
And hardly understood.
The King is now in progress towards Saint Albones,
With him, the Husband of this lovely Lady:
Thither goes these News,
As fast as Horse can carry them:
A sorry Breakfast for my Lord Protector.

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.l: Your Grace shall give me leave, my Lord of York,
To be the Post, in hope of his reward.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: At your pleasure, my good Lord.
Who is within there, ho?
Invite my Lords of Salisbury and Warwick
To sup with me tomorrow Night. Away.

body.stage: Enter the King, Queene, Protector, Cardinall, and Suffolke, with Faulkners hallowing.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: Believe me Lords, for flying at the Brooke,
I saw not better sport these seven years day:
Yet by your leave, the Wind was very high,
And ten to one, old Ioane had not gone out.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: But what a point, my Lord, your Falcon made,
And what a pitch she flew above the rest:
To see how God in all his Creatures works,
Yea Man and Birds are fain of climbing high.

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.l: No marvel, and it like your Majesty,
My Lord Protectors Hawks do tower so well,
They know their Master loves to be aloft,
And bears his thoughts above his Falcons Pitch.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: My Lord, it is but a base ignoble mind,
That mounts no higher than a Bird can sore:

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.p: I thought as much, he would be above the Clouds.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: Aye my Lord Cardinal, how think you by that?
Were it not good your Grace could fly to Heaven?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: The Treasury of everlasting Joy.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Thy Heaven is on Earth, thine Eyes and Thoughts
Beat on a Crown, the Treasure of thy Heart,
Pernicious Protector, dangerous Peer,
That smoothest it so with King and Common-weal.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: What, Cardinal?
Is your Priesthood grown peremptory?
Tantane animis Coelestibus irae, Church-men so hot?
Good Uncle hide such malice:
With such Holiness can you do it?

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.l: No malice Sir, no more than well becomes
So good a Quarrel, and so bad a Peer.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: As who, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.l: Why, as you, my Lord,
If it like your Lordly Lords Protectorship.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: Why Suffolke, England knows thine insolence.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: And thy Ambition, Gloster.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I prithee peace, good Queen,
And whet not on these furious Peers,
For blessed are the Peace-makers on Earth.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Let me be blessed for the Peace I make
Against this proud Protector with my Sword.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: Faith holy Uncle, would it were come to that.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Marry, when thou darest.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: Make up no factious numbers for the matter,
In thine own person answer thy abuse.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Aye, where thou darest not peep:
And if thou darest, this Evening,
On the East side of the Grove.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How now, my Lords?

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Believe me, Cousin Gloster,
Had not your man put up the Fowl so suddenly,
We had had more sport.
Come with thy two-hand Sword.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: True Uncle, are ye advised?
The East side of the Grove:
Cardinal, I am with you.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Why how now, Uncle Gloster?

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: Talking of Hawking; nothing else, my Lord.
Now by Gods Mother, Priest,
I will shave your Crown for this,
Or all my Fence shall fail.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.p: Medice terpsum, Protector see to it well, protect yourself.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: The Winds grow high,
So do your Stomachs, Lords:
How irksome is this Music to my heart?
When such Strings jar, what hope of Harmony?
I pray my Lords let me compound this strife.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: What means this noise?
Fellow, what Miracle dost thou proclaim?

sp.speaker: One.
sp.l: A Miracle, a Miracle.

sp.speaker: Suffolke.
sp.l: Come to the King, and tell him what Miracle.

sp.speaker: One.
sp.l: Forsooth, a blind man at Saint Albones Shrine,
Within this half hour hath received his sight,
A man that never saw in his life before.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Now God be praised, that to believing Souls
Gives Light in Darkness, Comfort in Despair.

body.stage: Enter the Maior of Saint Albones, and his Brethren, bearing the man betweene two in a Chayre.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Here comes the Townsmen, on Procession,
To present your Highness with the man.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Great is his comfort in this Earthly Vale,
Although by his sight his sin be multiplied.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: Stand by, my Masters, bring him near the King,
His Highness pleasure is to talk with him.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Good-fellow, tell us here the circumstance,
That we for thee may glorify the Lord.
What, hast thou been long blind, and now restored?

sp.speaker: Simpc.
sp.l: Borne blind, if it please your Grace.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Aye indeed was he.

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.l: What Woman is this?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: His Wife, if it like your Worship.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.p: Hadst thou been his Mother, thou couldst have better told.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Where wert thou borne?

sp.speaker: Simpc.
sp.p: At Barwick in the North, if it like your Grace.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Poor Soul,
Gods goodness hath been great to thee:
Let never Day nor Night unhallowed pass,
But still remember what the Lord hath done.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: Tell me, good-fellow,
Camest thou here by Chance, or of Devotion,
To this holy Shrine?

sp.speaker: Simpc.
sp.l: God knows of pure Devotion,
Being called a hundred times, and oftener,
In my sleep, by good Saint Albon:
Who said; Symon, come; come offer at my Shrine,
And I will help thee.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Most true, forsooth:
And many time and oft myself have heard a Voice,
To call him so.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: What, art thou lame?

sp.speaker: Simpc.
sp.l: I, God Almighty help me.

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.l: How camest thou so?

sp.speaker: Simpc.
sp.l: I fall off of a Tree.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: A Plum-tree, Master.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: How long hast thou been blind?

sp.speaker: Simpc.
sp.l: O borne so, Master.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: What, and wouldst climb a Tree?

sp.speaker: Simpc.
sp.l: But that in all my life, when I was a youth.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Too true, and bought his climbing very dear.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.p: By the mass, thou lovedest Plums well, that wouldst venture so.

sp.speaker: Simpc.
sp.p: Alas, good Master, my Wife desired some Damsons, and made me climb, with danger of my Life.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: A subtle Knave, but yet it shall not serve:
Let me see thine Eyes; wink now, now open them,
In my opinion, yet thou seest not well.

sp.speaker: Simpc.
sp.p: Yes Master, clear as day, I thank God and Saint Albones.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.p: Sayst thou me so: what Colour is this Cloak of?

sp.speaker: Simpc.
sp.p: Red Master, Red as Blood,

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.p: Why that is well said: What Colour is my Gown of?

sp.speaker: Simpc.
sp.p: Black forsooth, coal-black, as Jet.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Why then, thou knowest what Colour Jet is of?

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.p: And yet I think, Jet did he never see.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.p: But Cloaks and Gowns, before this day a many.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Never before this day, in all his life.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: Tell me Sirrah, what is my Name?

sp.speaker: Simpc.
sp.l: Alas Master, I know not.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: What is his Name?

sp.speaker: Simpc.
sp.l: I know not.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: Nor his?

sp.speaker: Simpc.
sp.l: No indeed, Master.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: What is thine own Name?

sp.speaker: Simpc.
sp.l: Saunder Simpcoxe, and if it please you, Master.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: Then Saunder, sit there,
The lyingest Knave in Christendom.
If thou hadst been borne blind,
Thou mightst as well have known all our Names,
As thus to name the several Colours we do wear.
Sight may distinguish of Colours:
But suddenly to nominate them all,
It is impossible.
My Lords, Saint Albone here hath done a Miracle:
And would ye not think it, Cunning to be great,
That could restore this Cripple to his Legs again.

sp.speaker: Simpc.
sp.l: O Master, that you could?

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: My Masters of Saint Albones,
Have you not Beadles in your Town,
And Things called Whips?

sp.speaker: Maior.
sp.l: Yes, my Lord, if it please your Grace.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: Then send for one presently.

sp.speaker: Maior.
sp.l: Sirrah, go fetch the Beadle hither straight.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.p: Now fetch me a Stool hither by and by. Now Sirrah, if you mean to save yourself from Whipping, leap me over this Stool, and run away.

sp.speaker: Simpc.
sp.l: Alas Master, I am not able to stand alone:
You go about to torture me in vain.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.p: Well Sir, we must have you find your Legs. Sirrah Beadle, whip him till he leap over that same Stool.

sp.speaker: Beadle.
sp.l: I will, my Lord.
Come on Sirrah, off with your Doublet, quickly.

sp.speaker: Simpc.
sp.p: Alas Master, what shall I do? I am not able to stand.

body.stage: After the Beadle hath hit him once, he leapes ouer the Stoole, and runnes away: and they follow, and cry, A Miracle.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O God, seest thou this, and bearest so long?

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: It made me laugh, to see the Villain run.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: Follow the Knave, and take this Drab away.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Alas Sir, we did it for pure need.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: Let them be whipped through every Market Town,
Till they come to Barwick, from whence they came.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Duke Humfrey has done a Miracle today.

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.l: True: made the Lame to leap and fly away.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: But you have done more Miracles than I:
You made in a day, my Lord, whole Towns to fly.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What Tidings with our Cousin Buckingham?

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.l: Such as my heart doth tremble to unfold:
A sort of naughty persons, lewdly bent,
Under the Countenance and Confederacy
Of Lady Elianor, the Protectors Wife,
The Ringleader and Head of all this Rout,
Have practised dangerously against your State,
Dealing with Witches and with Conjurers,
Whom we have apprehended in the Fact,
Raising up wicked Spirits from under ground,
Demanding of King Henries Life and Death,
And other of your Highness Privy Council,
As more at large your Grace shall understand.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: And so my Lord Protector, by this means
Your Lady is forthcoming, yet at London.
This News I think hath turned your Weapons edge;
It is like, my Lord, you will not keep your hour.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: Ambitious Church-man, leave to afflict my heart:
Sorrow and grief have vanquished all my powers;
And vanquished as I am, I yield to thee,
Or to the meanest Groom.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O God, what mischiefs work the wicked ones?
Heaping confusion on their own heads thereby.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: Gloster, see here the Tainture of thy Nest,
And look thyself be faultless, thou wert best.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: Madam, for myself, to Heaven I do appeal;
How I have loved my King, and Common-weal:
And for my Wife, I know not how it stands,
Sorry I am to hear what I have heard.
Noble she is: but if she have forgot
Honour and Virtue, and conversed with such,
As like to Pitch, defile Nobility;
I banish her my Bed, and Company,
And give her as a Prey to Law and Shame,
That hath dishonoured Glosters honest Name.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Well, for this Night we will repose us here:
Tomorrow toward London, back again,
To look into this Business thoroughly,
And call these foul Offenders to their Answers;
And poise the Cause in Justice equal Scales,
Whose Beam stands sure, whose rightful cause prevails.

body.stage: Flourish. Exeunt. Enter Yorke, Salisbury, and Warwick.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: Now my good Lords of Salisbury and Warwick,
Our simple Supper ended, give me leave,
In this close Walk, to satisfy myself,
In craving your opinion of my Title,
Which is infallible, to Englands Crown.

sp.speaker: Salisb.
sp.l: My Lord, I long to hear it at full.

sp.speaker: Warw.
sp.l: Sweet Yorke begin: and if thy claim be good,
The Neuills are thy Subjects to command.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: Then thus:
Edward the third, my Lords, had seven Sons:
The first, Edward the Black-Prince, Prince of Wales;
The second, William of Hatfield; and the third,
Lionel, Duke of Clarence; next to whom,
Was Iohn of Gaunt, the Duke of Lancaster;
The fifth, was Edmond Langley, Duke of Yorke;
The sixth, was Thomas of Woodstock, Duke of Gloster;
William of Windsor was the seventh, and last.
Edward the Black-Prince died before his Father,
And left behind him Richard, his only Son,
Who after Edward the third's death, reigned as King,
Till Henry Bullingbrooke, Duke of Lancaster,
The eldest Son and Heir of Iohn of Gaunt,
Crowned by the Name of Henry the fourth,
Seized on the Realm, deposed the rightful King,
Sent his poor Queen to France, from whence she came,
And him to Pumfret; where, as all you know,
Harmless Richard was murthered traitorously.

sp.speaker: Warw.
sp.l: Father, the Duke hath told the truth;
Thus got the House of Lancaster the Crown.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: Which now they hold by force, and not by right:
For Richard, the first Sons Heir, being dead,
The Issue of the next Son should have reigned.

sp.speaker: Salisb.
sp.p: But William of Hatfield died without an Heir.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: The third Son, Duke of Clarence,
From whose Line I claim, the Crown,
Had Issue Phillip, a Daughter,
Who married Edmond Mortimer, Earl of March:
Edmond had Issue, Roger, Earl of March;
Roger had Issue, Edmond, Anne, and Elianor.

sp.speaker: Salisb.
sp.l: This Edmond, in the Reign of Bullingbrooke,
As I have read, laid claim unto the Crown,
And but for Owen Glendour, had been King;
Who kept him in Captivity, till he died.
But, to the rest.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: His eldest Sister, Anne,
My Mother, being Heir unto the Crown,
Married Richard, Earl of Cambridge,
Who was to Edmond Langley,
Edward the thirds fifth Sons Son;
By her I claim the Kingdom:
She was Heir to Roger, Earl of March,
Who was the Son of Edmond Mortimer,
Who married Phillip, sole Daughter
Unto Lionel, Duke of Clarence.
So, if the Issue of the elder Son
Succeed before the younger, I am King.

sp.speaker: Warw.
sp.l: What plain proceedings is more plain than this?
Henry doth claim the Crown from Iohn of Gaunt,
The fourth Son, Yorke claims it from the third:
Till Lionels Issue fails, his should not reign.
It fails not yet, but flourishes in thee,
And in thy Sons, fair slips of such a Stock.
Then Father Salisbury, kneel we together,
And in this private Plot be we the first,
That shall salute our rightful Sovereign
With honour of his birthright to the Crown.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Long live our Sovereign Richard, Englands King.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: We thank you Lords:
But I am not your King, till I be Crowned,
And that my Sword be stained
With heart-blood of the House of Lancaster:
And that is not suddenly to be performed,
But with advice and silent secrecy.
Do you as I do in these dangerous days,
Wink at the Duke of Suffolkes insolence,
At Beaufords Pride, at Somersets Ambition,
At Buckingham, and all the Crew of them,
Till they have snared the Shepherd of the Flock,
That virtuous Prince, the good Duke Humfrey:
It is that they seek; and they, in seeking that,
Shall find their deaths, if Yorke can prophecy.

sp.speaker: Salisb.
sp.p: My Lord, break we off; we know your mind at full.

sp.speaker: Warw.
sp.l: My heart assures me, that the Earl of Warwick
Shall one day make the Duke of Yorke a King.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: And Neuill, this I do assure myself,
Richard shall live to make the Earl of Warwick
The greatest man in England, but the King.

body.stage: Exeunt. Sound Trumpets. Enter the King and State, with Guard, to banish the Duchesse.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Stand forth Dame Elianor Cobham,
Glosters Wife:
In sight of God, and us, your guilt is great,
Receive the Sentence of the Law for sin,
Such as by Gods Book are adjudged to death.
You four from hence to Prison, back again;
From thence, unto the place of Execution:
The Witch in Smithfield shall be burnt to ashes,
And you three shall be strangled on the Gallows.
You Madam, for you are more Nobly borne,
Despoiled of your Honour in your Life,
Shall, after three days open Penance done,
Live in your Country here, in Banishment,
With Sir Iohn Stanly, in the Isle of Man.

sp.speaker: Elianor.
sp.p: Welcome is Banishment, welcome were my Death.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: Elianor, the Law thou seest hath judged thee,
I cannot justify whom the Law condemns:
Mine eyes are full of tears, my heart of grief.
Ah Humfrey, this dishonour in thine age,
Will bring thy head with sorrow to the ground.
I beseech your Majesty give me leave to go;
Sorrow would solace, and mine Age would ease.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Stay Humfrey, Duke of Gloster,
Ere thou go, give up thy Staff,
Henry will to himself Protector be,
And God shall be my hope, my stay, my guide,
And Lantern to my feet:
And go in peace, Humfrey, no less beloved,
Than when thou wert Protector to thy King.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: I see no reason, why a King of years
Should be to be protected like a Child,
God and King Henry govern Englands Realm:
Give up your Staff, Sir, and the King his Realm.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: My Staff? Here, Noble Henry, is my Staff:
As willingly do I the same resign,
As ever thy Father Henry made it mine;
And even as willingly at thy feet I leave it,
As others would ambitiously receive it.
Farewell good King: when I am dead, and gone,
May honourable Peace attend thy Throne.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: Why now is Henry King, and Margaret Queen,
And Humfrey, Duke of Gloster, scarce himself,
That bears so shrewd a maim: two Pulls at once;
His Lady banished, and a Limb lopped off.
This Staff of Honour raught, there let it stand,
Where it best fits to be, in Henries hand.

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.l: Thus droops this lofty Pine, and hangs his sprays,
Thus Elianors Pride dies in her youngest days.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: Lords, let him go. Please it your Majesty,
This is the day appointed for the Combat,
And ready are the Appellant and Defendant,
The Armourer and his Man, to enter the Lists,
So please your Highness to behold the fight.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: Aye, good my Lord: for purposely therefore
Left I the Court, to see this Quarrel tried.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: In Gods Name see the Lists and all things fit,
Here let them end it, and God defend the right.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: I never saw a fellow worse bested,
Or more afraid to fight, than is the Appellant,
The servant of this Armourer, my Lords.

body.stage: Enter at one Doore the Armorer and his Neighbors, drinking to him so much, that hee is drunke; and he enters with a Drumme before him, and his Staffe, with a Sand-bagge fastened to it: and at the other Doore his Man, with a Drumme and Sand-bagge, and Prentices drinking to him.

sp.speaker: 1. Neighbor.
sp.p: Here Neighbour Horner, I drink to you in a Cup of Sack; and fear not Neighbour, you shall do well enough.

sp.speaker: 2. Neighbor.
sp.p: And here Neighbour, here is a Cup of Charneco.

sp.speaker: 3. Neighbor.
sp.p: And here is a Pot of good double-beer Neighbour: drink, and fear not your Man.

sp.speaker: Armorer.
sp.p: Let it come in faith, and I will pledge you all, and a fig for Peter.

sp.speaker: 1. Prent.
sp.p: Here Peter, I drink to thee, and be not afraid.

sp.speaker: 2. Prent.
sp.p: Be merry Peter, and fear not thy Master, Fight for credit of the Prentices.

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p:
I thank you all: drink, and pray for me, I pray you, for I think I have taken my last Draught in this World. Here Robin, and if I die, I give thee my Apron; and Will, thou shalt have my Hammer: and here Tom,
take all the Money that I have. O Lord bless me, I pray God, for I am never able to deal with my Master, he hath learnt so much sense already.

sp.speaker: Salisb.
sp.p: Come, leave your drinking, and fall to blows. Sirrah, what is thy Name.

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: Peter forsooth.

sp.speaker: Salisb.
sp.p: Peter? what more?

sp.speaker: Salisb.
sp.p: Thump? Then see thou thump thy Master well.

sp.speaker: Armorer.
sp.p: Masters, I am come hither as it were upon my Man's instigation, to prove him a Knave, and myself an honest man: and touching the Duke of Yorke, I will take my death, I never meant him any ill, nor the King, nor the Queen: and therefore Peter have at thee with a downright blow.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: Dispatch, this Knaves tongue begins to double.
Sound Trumpets, Alarum to the Combatants.

body.stage: They fight, and Peter strikes him downe.

sp.speaker: Armorer.
sp.p: Hold Peter, hold, I confess, I confess Treason.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.p: Take away his Weapon: Fellow thank God, and the good Wine in thy Masters way.

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: O God, have I overcome mine Enemies in this presence? O Peter, thou hast prevailed in right.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Go, take hence that Traitor from our sight,
For by his death we do perceive his guilt,
And God in Justice hath revealed to us
The truth and innocence of this poor fellow,
Which he had thought to have murthered wrongfully.
Come fellow, follow us for thy Reward.

body.stage: Sound a flourish. Exeunt. Enter Duke Humfrey and his Men in Mourning Cloakes.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: Thus sometimes hath the brightest day a Cloud:
And after Summer, evermore succeeds
Barren Winter, with his wrathful nipping Cold;
So Cares and Joys abound, as Seasons fleet.
Sirs, what is o'clock?

sp.speaker: Seru.
sp.l: Ten, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: Ten is the hour that was appointed me,
To watch the coming of my punished Duchess:
Underneath may she endure the Flinsie Streets,
To tread them with her tender-feeling feet.
Sweet Nell, ill can thy Noble Mind abrook
The abject People, gazing on thy face,
With envious Look a laughing at thy shame,
That erst did follow thy proud chariot-wheels,
When thou didst ride in triumph through the streets.
But soft, I think she comes, and I will prepare
My tear stained eyes, to see her Miseries.

body.stage: Enter the Duchesse in a white Sheet, and a Taper burning in her hand, with the Sherife and Officers.

sp.speaker: Seru.
sp.p: So please your Grace, we will ask her from the Sheriff.

sp.speaker: Gloster.
sp.p: No, stir not for your lives, let her pass by.

sp.speaker: Elianor.
sp.l: Come you, my Lord, to see my open shame?
Now thou dost Penance too. Look how they gaze,
See how the giddy multitude do point,
And nod their heads, and throw their eyes on thee.
Ah Gloster, hide thee from their hateful looks,
And in thy Closet pent up, rue my shame,
And ban thine Enemies, both mine and thine.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: Be patient, gentle Nell, forget this grief.

sp.speaker: Elianor.
sp.l: Ah Gloster, teach me to forget myself:
For whilst I think I am thy married Wife,
And thou a Prince, Protector of this Land,
Methinks I should not thus be led along,
Mailed up in shame, with Papers on my back.
And followed with a Rabble, that rejoice
To see my tears, and hear my deep set groans.
The ruthless Flint doth cut my tender feet,
And when I start, the envious people laugh,
And bid me be advised how I tread.
Ah Humfrey, can I bear this shameful yoke?
Trowest thou, that ere I will look upon the World,
Or count them happy, that enjoys the Sun?
No: Dark shall be my Light, and Night my Day.
To think upon my Pomp, shall be my Hell.
Sometime I will say, I am Duke Humfreyes Wife,
And he a Prince, and Ruler of the Land:
Yet so he ruled, and such a Prince he was,
As he stood by, whilst I, his forlorn Duchess,
Was made a wonder, and a pointing stock
To every idle Rascal follower.
But be thou mild, and blush not at my shame,
Nor stir at nothing, till the Axe of Death
Hang over thee, as sure it shortly will.
For Suffolke, he that can do all in all
With her, that hateth thee and hates us all,
And Yorke, and impious Beauford, that false Priest,
Have all limed Bushes to betray thy Wings,
And fly thou how thou canst, they will tangle thee.
But fear not thou, until thy foot be snared,
Nor never seek prevention of thy foes.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: Ah Nell, forbear: thou aimest all awry.
I must offend, before I be attainted:
And had I twenty times so many foes,
And each of them had twenty times their power,
All these could not procure me any scathe,
So long as I am loyal, true, and crimeless.
Wouldst have me rescue thee from this reproach?
Why yet thy scandal were not wiped away,
But I in danger for the breach of Law.
Thy greatest help is quiet, gentle Nell:
I pray thee sort thy heart to patience,
These few days wonder will be quickly worn:

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: I summon your Grace to his Majesties Parliament,
Holden at Bury, the first of this next Month.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: And my consent never asked herein before?
This is close dealing. Well, I will be there.
My Nell, I take my leave: and Master Sheriff,
Let not her Penance exceed the Kings Commission.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: If it please your Grace, here my Commission stays:
And Sir Iohn Stanly is appointed now,
To take her with him to the Isle of Man.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: Must you, Sir Iohn, protect my Lady here?

sp.speaker: Stanly.
sp.p: So am I given in charge, may it please your Grace.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: Entreat her not the worse, in that I pray
You use her well: the World may laugh again,
And I may live to do you kindness, if you do it her.
And so Sir Iohn, farewell.

sp.speaker: Elianor.
sp.l: What, gone my Lord, and bid me not farewell?

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: Witness my tears, I cannot stay to speak.

sp.speaker: Elianor.
sp.l: Art thou gone too? all comfort go with thee,
For none abides with me: my Joy, is Death;
Death, at whose Name I oft have been afeared,
Because I wished this Worlds eternity.
Stanley, I prithee go, and take me hence,
I care not whither, for I beg no favour;
Only convey me where thou art commanded.

sp.speaker: Stanley.
sp.l: Why, Madam, that is to the Isle of Man,
There to be used according to your State.

sp.speaker: Elianor.
sp.l: That is bad enough, for I am but reproach:
And shall I then be used reproachfully?

sp.speaker: Stanley.
sp.l: Like to a Duchess, and Duke Humfreyes Lady,
According to that State you shall be used.

sp.speaker: Elianor.
sp.l: Sheriff farewell, and better than I fare,
Although thou hast been Conduct of my shame.

sp.speaker: Sherife.
sp.l: It is my Office, and Madam pardon me.

sp.speaker: Elianor.
sp.l: Aye, Aye, farewell, thy Office is discharged:
Come Stanley, shall we go?

sp.speaker: Stanley.
sp.l: Madam, your Penance done,
Throw off this Sheet,
And go we to attire you for our Journey.

sp.speaker: Elianor.
sp.l: My shame will not be shifted with my Sheet:
No it will hang upon my richest Robes,
And show itself, attire me how I can.
Go, lead the way, I long to see my Prison.

body.stage: Sound a Senet. Enter King, Queene, Cardinall, Suffolke, Yorke, Buckingham, Salisbury, and Warwicke, to the Parliament.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I muse my Lord of Gloster is not come:
It is not his wont to be the hindmost man,
What ever occasion keeps him from us now.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: Can you not see? or will ye not observe
The strangeness of his altered Countenance?
With what a Majesty he bears himself,
How insolent of late he is become,
How proud, how peremptory, and unlike himself.
We know the time since he was mild and affable,
And if we did but glance a far off Look,
Immediately he was upon his Knee,
That all the Court admired him for submission.
But meet him now, and be it in the Morn,
When every one will give the time of day,
He knits his Brow, and shows an angry Eye,
And passeth by with stiff unbowed Knee,
Disdaining duty that to us belongs.
Small Curs are not regarded when they grin,
But great men tremble when the Lion roars,
And Humfrey is no little Man in England.
First note, that he is near you in descent,
And should you fall, he is the next will mount.
Me seemeth then, it is no Policy,
Respecting what a rancorous mind he bears,
And his advantage following your decease,
That he should come about your Royal Person,
Or be admitted to your Highness Council.
By flattery hath he won the Commons hearts:
And when he please to make Commotion,
It is to be feared they all will follow him.
Now it is the Spring, and Weeds are shallow-rooted,
Suffer them now, and they will overgrow the Garden,
And choke the Herbs for want of Husbandry.
The reverent care I bear unto my Lord,
Made me collect these dangers in the Duke.
If it be fond, call it a Woman's fear:
Which fear, if better Reasons can supplant,
I will subscribe, and say I wronged the Duke.
My Lord of Suffolke, Buckingham, and Yorke,
Reprove my allegation, if you can,
Or else conclude my words effectual.

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.l: Well hath your Highness seen into this Duke:
And had I first been put to speak my mind,
I think I should have told your Graces Tale.
The Duchess, by his subornation,
Upon my Life began her devilish practises:
Or if he were not privy to those Faults,
Yet by reputing of his high descent,
As next the King, he was successive Heir,
And such high vaunts of his Nobility,
Did instigate the Bedlam brainsick Duchess,
By wicked means to frame our Sovereigns fall.
Smooth runs the Water, where the Brooke is deep,
And in his simple show he harbours Treason.
The Fox barks not, when he would steal the Lamb.
No, no, my Sovereign, Glouster is a man
Unsounded yet, and full of deep deceit.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Did he not, contrary to form of Law,
Devise strange deaths, for small offences done?

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: And did he not, in his Protectorship,
Levy great sums of Money through the Realm,
For Soldiers pay in France, and never sent it?
By means whereof, the Towns each day revolted.

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.l: Tut, these are petty faults to faults unknown,
Which time will bring to light in smooth Duke Humfrey.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: My Lords at once: the care you have of us
To mow down Thorns that would annoy our Foot,
Is worthy praise: but shall I speak my conscience,
Our Kinsman Gloster is as innocent,
From meaning Treason to our Royal Person,
As is the sucking Lamb, or harmless Dove:
The Duke is virtuous, mild, and too well given,
To dream on evil, or to work my downfall.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Ah what is more dangerous, than this fond affiance?
Seems he a Dove? his feathers are but borrowed,
For he is disposed as the hateful Raven.
Is he a Lamb? his Skin is surely lent him,
For he is inclined as is the ravenous Wolves.
Who cannot steal a shape, that means deceit?
Take heed, my Lord, the welfare of us all,
Hangs on the cutting short that fraudful man.

sp.speaker: Som.
sp.l: All health unto my gracious Sovereign.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Welcome Lord Somerset: What News from France?

sp.speaker: Som.
sp.l: That all your Interest in those Territories,
Is utterly bereft you: all is lost.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Cold News, Lord Somerset: but Gods will be done.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: Cold News for me: for I had hope of France,
As firmly as I hope for fertile England.
Thus are my Blossoms blasted in the Bud,
And Caterpillars eat my Leaves away:
But I will remedy this gear ere long,
Or sell my Title for a glorious Grave.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: All happiness unto my Lord the King:
Pardon, my Liege, that I have stayed so long.

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.l: Nay Gloster, know that thou art come too soon,
Unless thou wert more loyal than thou art:
I do arrest thee of High Treason here.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: Well Suffolke, thou shalt not see me blush,
Nor change my Countenance for this Arrest:
A Heart unspotted, is not easily daunted.
The purest Spring is not so free from mud,
As I am clear from Treason to my Sovereign.
Who can accuse me? wherein am I guilty?

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: It is thought, my Lord,
That you took Bribes of France,
And being Protector, stayed the Soldiers pay,
By means whereof, his Highness hath lost France.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: Is it but thought so?
What are they that think it?
I never robbed the Soldiers of their pay,
Nor ever had one penny Bribe from France.
So help me God, as I have watched the Night,
Aye, Night by Night, in studying good for England.
That Doit that ere I wrested from the King,
Or any Groat I hoarded to my use,
Be brought against me at my Trial day.
No: many a Pound of mine own proper store,
Because I would not tax the needy Commons,
Have I disbursed to the Garrisons,
And never asked for restitution.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: It serves you well, my Lord, to say so much.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: I say no more than truth, so help me God.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: In your Protectorship, you did devise
Strange Tortures for Offenders, never heard of,
That England was defamed by Tyranny.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: Why it is well known, that whiles I was Protector,
Pity was all the fault that was in me:
For I should melt at an Offenders tears,
And lowly words were Ransom for their fault:
Unless it were a bloody Murtherer,
Or foul felonious Thief, that fleeced poor passengers,
I never gave them condign punishment.
Murther indeed, that bloody sin, I tortured
Above the Felon, or what Trespass else.

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.l: My Lord, these faults are easy, quickly answered:
But mightier Crimes are laid unto your charge,
Whereof you cannot easily purge yourself.
I do arrest you in his Highness Name,
And here commit you to my Lord Cardinal
To keep, until your further time of Trial.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: My Lord of Gloster, it is my special hope,
That you will clear yourself from all suspense,
My Conscience tells me you are innocent.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: Ah gracious Lord, these days are dangerous:
Virtue is choked with foul Ambition,
And Charity chased hence by Rancours hand;
Foul Subornation is predominant,
And Equity exiled your Highness Land.
I know, their Complot is to have my Life:
And if my death might make this Island happy,
And prove the Period of their Tyranny,
I would expend it with all willingness.
But mine is made the Prologue to their Play:
For thousands more, that yet suspect no peril,
Will not conclude their plotted Tragedy.
Beaufords red sparkling eyes blab his hearts malice,
And Suffolks cloudy Brow his stormy hate;
Sharpe Buckingham unburdens with his tongue,
The envious Load that lies upon his heart:
And dogged Yorke, that reaches at the Moon,
Whose overweaning Arm I have plucked back,
By false accuse doth level at my Life.
And you, my Sovereign Lady, with the rest,
Causeless have laid disgraces on my head,
And with your best endeavour have stirred up
My liefest Liege to be mine Enemy:
Aye, all of you have laid your heads together,
Myself had notice of your Conventicles,
And all to make away my guiltless Life.
I shall not want false Witness, to condemn me,
Nor store of Treasons, to augment my guilt:
The ancient Proverb will be well effected,
A Staff is quickly found to beat a Dog.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: My Liege, his railing is intolerable.
If those that care to keep your Royal Person
From Treasons secret Knife, and Traitors Rage,
Be thus upbraided, chid, and rated at,
And the Offender granted scope of speech,
It will make them cool in zeal unto your Grace.

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.l: Hath he not twit our Sovereign Lady here
With ignominious words, though Clerkly couched?
As if she had suborned some to swear
False allegations, to overthrow his state.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: But I can give the loser leave to chide.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: Far truer spoke than meant: I lose indeed,
Beshrew the winners, for they played me false,
And well such losers may have leave to speak.

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.l: He will wrest the sense, and hold us here all day.
Lord Cardinal, he is your Prisoner.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Sirs, take away the Duke, and guard him sure.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: Ah, thus King Henry throws away his Crutch,
Before his Legs be firm to bear his Body.
Thus is the Shepherd beaten from thy side,
And Wolves are gnarling, who shall gnaw thee first.
Ah that my fear were false, ah that it were;
or good King Henry, thy decay I fear.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: My Lords, what to your wisdoms seemeth best,
Do, or undo, as if ourself were here.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: What, will your Highness leave the Parliament?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Aye Margaret: my heart is drowned with grief,
Whose flood begins to flow within mine eyes;
My Body round engirt with misery:
For what is more miserable than Discontent?
Ah Uncle Humfrey, in thy face I see
The Map of Honour, Truth, and Loyalty:
And yet, good Humfrey, is the hour to come,
That ever I proved thee false, or feared thy faith.
What lowering Star now envies thy estate?
That these great Lords, and Margaret our Queen,
Do seek subversion of thy harmless Life.
Thou never didst them wrong, nor no man wrong:
And as the Butcher takes away the Calf,
And binds the Wretch, and beats it when it strays,
Bearing it to the bloody Slaughter-house;
Even so remorseless have they borne him hence:
And as the Dam runs lowing up and down,
Looking the way her harmless young one went,
And can do naught but wail her Darlings loss;
Even so myself bewails good Glosters case
With sad unhelpful tears, and with dimmed eyes;
Look after him, and cannot do him good:
So mighty are his vowed Enemies.
His fortunes I will weep, and twixt each groan,
Say, who is a Traitor? Gloster he is none.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: Free Lords:
Cold Snow melts with the Suns hot Beams:
Henry, my Lord, is cold in great Affairs,
Too full of foolish pity: and Glosters show
Beguiles him, as the mournful Crocodile
With sorrow snares relenting passengers;
Or as the Snake, rolled in a flowering Bank,
With shining checkered slough doth sting a Child,
That for the beauty thinks it excellent.
Believe me Lords, were none more wise than I,
And yet herein I judge mine own Wit good;
This Gloster should be quickly rid the World,
To rid us from the fear we have of him.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: That he should die, is worthy policy,
But yet we want a Colour for his death:
It is meet he be condemned by course of Law.

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.l: But in my mind, that were no policy:
The King will labour still to save his Life,
The Commons happily rise, to save his Life;
And yet we have but trivial argument,
More than mistrust, that shows him worthy death.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: So that by this, you would not have him die.

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.l: Ah Yorke, no man alive, so fain as I.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: It is Yorke that hath more reason for his death.
But my Lord Cardinal, and you my Lord of Suffolke,
Say as you think, and speak it from your Souls:
Were it not all one, an empty Eagle were set,
To guard the Chicken from a hungry Kite,
As place Duke Humfrey for the Kings Protector?

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: So the poor Chicken should be sure of death.

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.l: Madam it is true: and were it not madness then,
To make the Fox surveyor of the Fold?
Who being accused a crafty Murtherer,
His guilt should be but idly posted over,
Because his purpose is not executed.
No: let him die, in that he is a Fox,
By nature proved an Enemy to the Flock,
Before his Chaps be stained with Crimson blood,
As Humfrey proved by Reasons to my Liege.
And do not stand on Quillets how to slay him:
Be it by Gins, by Snares, by Subtlety,
Sleeping, or Waking, it is no matter how,
So he be dead; for that is good deceit,
Which mates him first, that first intends deceit.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: Thrice Noble Suffolke, it is resolutely spoke.

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.l: Not resolute, except so much were done,
For things are often spoke, and seldom meant,
But that my heart accordeth with my tongue,
Seeing the deed is meritorious,
And to preserve my Sovereign from his Foe,
Say but the word, and I will be his Priest.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: But I would have him dead, my Lord of Suffolke,
Ere you can take due Orders for a Priest:
Say you consent, and censure well the deed,
And I will provide his Executioner,
I tender so the safety of my Liege.

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.l: Here is my Hand, the deed is worthy doing.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: And so say I.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: And I: and now we three have spoke it,
It skills not greatly who impugns our doom.

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.l: Great Lords, from Ireland am I come amain,
To signify, that Rebels there are up,
And put the Englishmen unto the Sword.
Send Succours (Lords) and stop the Rage betime,
Before the Wound do grow uncurable;
For being green, there is great hope of help.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: A Breach that craves a quick expedient stop.
What counsel give you in this weighty cause?

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: That Somerset be sent as Regent thither:
It is meet that lucky Ruler be employed,
Witness the fortune he hath had in France.

sp.speaker: Som.
sp.l: If Yorke, with all his far fet policy,
Had been the Regent there, in stead of me,
He never would have stayed in France so long.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: No, not to lose it all, as thou hast done.
I rather would have lost my Life betimes,
Than bring a burthen of dishonour home,
By staying there so long, till all were lost.
Show me one scar, charactered on thy Skin,
Men's flesh preserved so whole, do seldom win.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Nay, then this spark will prove a raging fire,
If Wind and Fuel be brought, to feed it with:
No more, good Yorke; sweet Somerset be still.
Thy fortune, Yorke, hadst thou been Regent there,
Might happily have proved far worse than his.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.p: What, worse than naught? nay, then a shame take all.

sp.speaker: Somerset.
sp.p: And in the number, thee, that wishest shame.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: My Lord of Yorke, try what your fortune is:
The uncivil Kerns of Ireland are in Arms,
And temper Clay with blood of Englishmen.
To Ireland will you lead a Band of men,
Collected choicely, from each County some,
And try your hap against the Irishmen?

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: I will, my Lord, so please his Majesty.

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.l: Why, our Authority is his consent,
And what we do establish, he confirms:
Then, Noble Yorke, take thou this Task in hand.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: I am content: Provide me Soldiers, Lords,
Whiles I take order for mine own affairs.

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.l: A charge, Lord Yorke, that I will see performed.
But now return we to the false Duke Humfrey.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: No more of him: for I will deal with him,
That henceforth he shall trouble us no more:
And so break off, the day is almost spent,
Lord Suffolke, you and I must talk of that event.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: My Lord of Suffolke, within fourteen days
At Bristow I expect my Soldiers,
For there I will ship them all for Ireland.

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.l: I will see it truly done, my Lord of Yorke.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: Now Yorke, or never, steel thy fearful thoughts,
And change misdoubt to resolution;
Be that thou hopest to be, or what thou art;
Resign to death, it is not worth the enjoying.
Let pale faced fear keep with the mean born man,
And find no harbour in a Royal heart.
Faster the Spring-time showers, comes thought on thought,
And not a thought, but thinks on Dignity.
My Brain, more busy than the labouring Spider,
Weaves tedious Snares to trap mine Enemies.
Well Nobles, well: it is politically done,
To send me packing with an Host of men:
I fear me, you but warm the starved Snake,
Who cherished in your breasts, will sting your hearts.
It was men I lacked, and you will give them me;
I take it kindly: yet be well assured,
You put sharpe Weapons in a madman's hands.
Whiles I in Ireland nourish a mighty Band,
I will stir up in England some black Storm,
Shall blow ten thousand Souls to Heaven, or Hell:
And this fell Tempest shall not cease to rage,
Until the Golden Circuit on my Head,
Like to the glorious Suns transparent Beams,
Do calm the fury of this mad-bred Flaw.
And for a minister of my intent,
I have seduced a headstrong Kentishman,
Iohn Cade of Ashford,
To make Commotion, as full well he can,
Under the Title of Iohn Mortimer.
In Ireland have I seen this stubborn Cade
Oppose himself against a Troupe of Kerns,
And fought so long, till that his thighs with Darts
Were almost like a sharp quilled Porpentine:
And in the end being rescued, I have seen
Him caper upright, like a wild Morisco,
Shaking the bloody Darts, as he his Bells.
Full often, like a shag-haired crafty Kern,
Hath he conversed with the Enemy,
And undiscovered, come to me again,
And given me notice of their Villainies.
This Devil here shall be my substitute;
For that Iohn Mortimer, which now is dead,
In face, in gate, in speech he doth resemble.
By this, I shall perceive the Commons mind,
How they affect the House and Claim of Yorke.
Say he be taken, racked, and tortured;
I know, no pain they can inflict upon him,
Will make him say, I moved him to those Arms.
Say that he thrive, as it is great like he will,
Why then from Ireland come I with my strength,
And reap the Harvest which that Rascal sowed.
For Humfrey; being dead, as he shall be,
And Henry put apart: the next for me.

body.stage: Exit. Enter two or three running ouer the Stage, from the Murther of Duke Humfrey.

sp.l: Run to my Lord of Suffolke: let him know
We have dispatched the Duke, as he commanded.
O that it were to do: what have we done?
Didst ever hear a man so penitent?
Here comes my Lord.

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.l: Now Sirs, have you dispatched this thing?
aye, my good Lord, he is dead.

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.l: Why that is well said. Go, get you to my House,
I will reward you for this venturous deed:
The King and all the Peers are here at hand.
Have you laid fair the Bed? Is all things well,
According as I gave directions?
It is, my good Lord.

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.l: Away, be gone.

body.stage: Exeunt. Sound Trumpets. Enter the King, the Queene, Cardinall, Suffolke; Somerset, with Attendants.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Go call our Uncle to our presence straight: I
Say, we intend to try his Grace today,
If he be guilty, as it is published.

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.l: I will call him presently, my Noble Lord.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Lords take your places: and I pray you all
Proceed no straighter against our Uncle Gloster,
than from true evidence, of good esteem,
He be approved in practise culpable.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: God forbid any Malice should prevail,
That faultless may condemn a Nobleman:
Pray God he may acquit him of suspicion.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: I thank thee Nell, these words content me much.
sp.l: How now? why lookest thou pale? why tremblest thou?
Where is our Uncle? what is the matter, Suffolke?

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.l: Dead in his Bed, my Lord: Gloster is dead.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: Marry God forfend.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Gods secret Judgment: I did dream tonight,
The Duke was dumb, and could not speak a word.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p:
How fares my Lord? Help Lords, the King is
dead.

sp.speaker: Som.
sp.l: Rear up his Body, wring him by the Nose.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Run, go, help, help: Oh Henry ope thine eyes.

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.l: He doth revive again, Madam be patient.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O Heavenly God.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: How fares my gracious Lord?

sp.speaker: Suff.
sp.l: Comfort my Sovereign, gracious Henry comfort.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What, doth my Lord of Suffolke comfort me?
Came he right now to sing a Ravens Note,
Whose dismal tune bereft my Vital powers:
And thinks he, that the chirping of a Wren,
By crying comfort from a hollow breast,
Can chase away the first conceived sound?
Hide not thy poison with such sugared words,
Lay not thy hands on me: forbear I say,
